instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
[B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
not charging battery[/B]


​​​​​​Irregular readings I noticed:

​​​​​​<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.3V

SDA Battery Data Line = 3.2V

SMC Reset is Good

Is this a bad SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message: Either bad ISL or bad SMC. You can start by removing edge bonding on SMC and giving it some flux and heat. 12.3 makes me think it’s possible the SMC isn’t dead yet has crap under it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
Okay I will try this on the SMC, tried a couple new ISL already.

Before we confirm SMC anything else I can try?
​​​​​

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
SCL/SDA lines on diode mode cannot give more than 1% difference, respect to ground.
If not, remove <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> and check again.
BIL connector is supposed to be disconnected, of course.
Next step, if needed, remove <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and test again.
If still get difference with only SMC on that bus, gues what?
BTW, try first to reflow it with good flux; could be only crap under SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message: SCL/SDA lines on diode mode give equal reading  ~ .5

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
.5 is completely irrelevant...
As I already told you lees than 5% difference.
Fot example, .485/.500 is too much difference.
Try to post correct information.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message: Yes I can confirm less than 5percent difference on both readings. They are equal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
I noticed on this thread that a similar issue was solved by changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>:

[url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/1110-solved-<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>-low-voltage-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-not-charging-fixed-via-<TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>[/url]


Should I try this before messing around with the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
Is <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> bad in your case?

"lees than 5% difference"
My fault; should be 1%, like in the previous post...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message: How can I effectively test if <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> is bad?  It gets the 12.3V in but does not go out, pin 4 stuck at 12.3V .  Pin 5 has a dropping voltage.. Starts around 4v continually lowers, rate of decrease slows as it gets lower.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL> must go low to enable battery charging.
Pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> should maintain the battery voltage.
Did you try known good battery?
Check if <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> is OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> is good, battery is known good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
Do you get the battery voltage at <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> pin 5?
Test the battery voltage on other board, then check back in this one...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
threads.message:
Changed SMC everything appears to be working perfectly now!

Thanks everyone
